channel.title: BBC News - Asia

item.title: New Zealand PM Ardern says supermarket stabbing was 'terrorist attack'
item.description: Videos online show panicked shoppers running out of the Countdown supermarket at LynnMall.

item.title: Afghanistan Panjshir: Fighting intensifies over holdout Afghan valley
item.description: The Panjshir Valley, near Kabul, is the only area of Afghanistan that has not fallen to the Taliban.

item.title: North Korea: Kim Jong-un asks officials to tackle food shortage
item.description: The country's economy has been battered by sanctions and restrictions to prevent the spread of Covid.

item.title: Yoshihide Suga to step down as Japan's prime minister
item.description: Mr Suga had been appointed to the role just a year ago following the resignation of Shinzo Abe.

item.title: Study links air pollution with obesity and asthma among children
item.description: The study advises urgent action to control air pollution in cities like Delhi.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: China's armless swimmer Zheng Tao dominates with four golds
item.description: The 30-year-old, who lost his arms from an electric shock, dominated the Games pool with four golds.

item.title: China set to open new stock exchange in Beijing
item.description: The announcement comes as Chinese firms come under intense scrutiny both at home and in the US.

item.title: TCS: India's largest private employer returns to office
item.description: IT services giant TCS says it's ready to go back to the office after 18 months - how will that work?

item.title: Climate-above-all plea by US fails to stir China
item.description: Envoy John Kerry's 'it's more important than politics' appeal falls on deaf ears.

item.title: China's media cracks down on 'effeminate' styles
item.description: The media regulator says it will shun "vulgar influencers" while casting a spotlight on stars' pay.

item.title: Afghanistan: Facebook says it helped people flee, including staff
item.description: The flight arrived in Mexico City on Wednesday, with 175 Afghan citizens on board, including 75 children.

item.title: Afghan evacuee boy who ate poisonous mushrooms dies in Poland
item.description: The five year old ate the mushrooms at a refugee centre near Warsaw after his evacuation from Kabul.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Anger after Paralympian is stripped of gold medal for being late
item.description: Muhammad Ziyad Zolkefli won his shot put event but had his title revoked because he was three minutes late.

item.title: Syed Ali Shah Geelani: The man who fought for Kashmir’s freedom
item.description: Syed Ali Shah Geelani believed India should not rule the region and never changed his stand.

item.title: How North Korea’s founding father, Kim Il-sung, came to power
item.description: Professor Kim Hyung-suk had breakfast with the man who would rule North Korea for nearly 50 years

item.title: Shang-Chi: Why Marvel's first Asian superhero is empowering change
item.description: Shang-Chi And The Legend Of The Ten Rings sees Simu Liu front an Asian-led cast. Why does it matter?

item.title: China steps in to regulate brutal '996' work culture
item.description: Workers in China are fed up with the brutal 12-hour work days once seen as a key driver of success.

item.title: Beaten and humiliated by Hindu mobs for being a Muslim in India
item.description: Attacks on Muslims by Hindu mobs have risen in India, with little apparent official condemnation.

item.title: Amid violent reprisals, Afghans fear the Taliban's 'amnesty' was empty
item.description: Reports suggest the Taliban are searching for, and allegedly killing, people they pledged to leave in peace.

item.title: Afghanistan women's cricket team: Players hiding in Kabul fear Taliban rule
item.description: Members of Afghanistan's women's cricket team are hiding in Kabul, fearing for their safety following the Taliban's return to power.
